pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw:
So I don't have any non-cosmo datasets to work with. I'll see if someone else does.

I will say the unit system is very weird with ramses, in that at least for cosmo runs I have to divide by unit_t when I calculate the sim time (and later the star ages). This is because later on yt will multiply these by the codeunits because it expects them to be in code units. This suggests that multiplying by unit_time in the original version of data_structures was definitely wrong, because you'll end up doing it again later on.

As I said, I'll see if I can find another data set to check this on. In the meantime, is there a way to change the test to be for a set unit (ie seconds?). That seems more future safe in case default units change.
content.html:
So I don't have any non-cosmo datasets to work with. I'll see if someone else does.

I will say the unit system is very weird with ramses, in that at least for cosmo runs I have to divide by unit_t when I calculate the sim time (and later the star ages). This is because later on yt will multiply these by the codeunits because it expects them to be in code units. This suggests that multiplying by unit_time in the original version of data_structures was definitely wrong, because you'll end up doing it again later on.

As I said, I'll see if I can find another data set to check this on. In the meantime, is there a way to change the test to be for a set unit (ie seconds?). That seems more future safe in case default units change.

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw:
I don't know if this helps, but for a non-cosmo snapshot of mine I get that (on the dev version of yt):

```
#!python

>>> ds.current_time.value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True
```

EDIT: to be a bit more explicit:


```
#!python

>>> ds['unit_t']
4.70430312424e+14
>>> ds['time']
1.91661293229
>>> ds.current_time.value
9.01632820534e+14
>>> ds.current_time
9.01632820534e+14 code_time
```
content.html:
I don't know if this helps, but for a non-cosmo snapshot of mine I get that (on the dev version of yt):

>>> ds.current_time.value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True

EDIT: to be a bit more explicit:

>>> ds['unit_t']
4.70430312424e+14
>>> ds['time']
1.91661293229
>>> ds.current_time.value
9.01632820534e+14
>>> ds.current_time
9.01632820534e+14 code_time

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.html:
It isn't...

>>> ds['time'] == ds.current_time
False

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw:
The issue was that the stored time was not dimensionless only if the simulation was not cosmological (because of the if statement, line 649). It was not affecting cosmological ones, as far as this section is concerned.
[EDIT: how can I delete this comment? I answered too quickly]
content.html: The issue was that the stored time was not dimensionless only if the simulation was not cosmological (because of the if statement, line 649). It was not affecting cosmological ones, as far as this section is concerned. [EDIT: how can I delete this comment? I answered too quickly]

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw: But this is just what is set in the original data_structures here, no? That doesn't mean ds.current_time.value is actually the right value, just that it still agrees with how it was previously set on line 650.
content.html: But this is just what is set in the original data_structures here, no? That doesn't mean ds.current_time.value is actually the right value, just that it still agrees with how it was previously set on line 650.

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw: FWIW, ds['time'] is the same as ds.parameters['time'], so I don't think it's particularly surprising that you get that result given the way `ds.current_time` is calculated right now.
content.html: FWIW, ds['time'] is the same as ds.parameters['time'], so I don't think it's particularly surprising that you get that result given the way ds.current_time is calculated right now.

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw:
Shouldn't we expect
```python
>>> s.current_time.in_units('s)].value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True
```
instead?

With the version pushed here with my dataset, I have
```python
>>> s.current_time.in_units('s)].value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True
>>> ds['time'] == ds.current_time
True
```
content.html:
Shouldn't we expect

>>> s.current_time.in_units('s)].value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True

instead?

With the version pushed here with my dataset, I have

>>> s.current_time.in_units('s)].value == ds['time'] * ds['unit_t']
True
>>> ds['time'] == ds.current_time
True

pullrequest.title: Fix issue that was converting twice the time

content.raw: Yeah, I agree with @cphyc's analysis. In addition, I expect `ds.current_time.in_units('s')` in the example @ruggiero was working with above is incorrect.
content.html: Yeah, I agree with Corentin Cadiou's analysis. In addition, I expect ds.current_time.in_units('s') in the example Rafael Ruggiero was working with above is incorrect.

>>> ds.current_time.to('s')
4.24155409455e+29 s
